title: Stranded travellers coming home
text:
Over 6000 stranded travellers will return to Australia from Bali today if flying conditions remain clear. Sky News 14 Jul 2015 News Mount Raung ... Volcanic material spewed from Indonesia’s volcano glows in the night. Picture: AP/Trisnadi Source: AP 
QANTAS has joined the Bali retrieval effort partnering with Jetstar to bring Australian travellers home. 
The Flying Kangaroo on Tuesday night flew two empty Boeing 737 aircraft to Bali to bring nearly 350 people back to Perth. 
Jetstar returned around 2000 travellers on Tuesday, and has scheduled 19 services on Wednesday to bring back another 3000. 
Virgin Australia is also making the most of the clear conditions in Bali, planning 15 flights on Wednesday, in addition to the 18 flown on Tuesday. 
Normal services could resume by Thursday if the ash plume remains clear of Denpasar airport. 
The advice from the Volcanic Ash Advisory Centre, is winds will continue to blow the plume to the south of Bali. Long wait ... Kobe Rose, 10, waits for his mum's arrival at Melbourne International Airport. Picture: Luis Ascui/Getty Source: Getty Images 
Senior meteorologist Stephanie Bond said a decrease in the force of eruptions from Mount Raung in Java was also helping to keep Bali clear of ash. 
“Unfortunately the decrease is no indication the eruptions are nearing an end,” said Ms Bond. 
“Volcanoes are unpredictable and it’s very hard to say when eruptions might stop.” 
The flight disruption began a week ago, resulting in the cancellation of an estimated 80 services by Jetstar and Virgin Australia. 
As a result thousands of people were stranded in Bali for days as they waited to be rebooked on flights. 
Kerryn Heffernan had planned to return home to Melbourne last Thursday but now faces a marathon 20-hour journey to get back. 
She was rebooked to fly to Perth last night, followed by an eight-hour wait to board another flight to Melbourne, and then a two-hour drive. 
“I will be glad to get to Australia,” said Ms Heffernan, who was travelling with her son and his family. Trying to get home ... Passengers queue at Ngurah airport in Denpasar. Picture: AFP/SONNYTUMBELAKA Source: AFP 
“I will be glad when the plane takes off but it will be very cold in Australia. 
“We have had a lovely holiday but we are all ready to go home.” 
In an effort to help people avoid further disruption from the troublesome ash cloud, Virgin Australia is offering those booked to go to Bali in coming weeks, the chance to change destinations at no extra cost. 
The only catch is choices are limited to 12 destinations, including Fiji, Samoa, Thailand, Vanuatu and Cairns. 
Both airlines have warned more flights could be cancelled if the ash cloud returns. Bali tourists facing budget blowout 
Travellers are learning a harsh lesson about the need for insurance, with many seeing their “cheap” Bali holiday blow out by thousands as a result of the volcanic ash cloud. 
The insurance industry estimates as many as 30 per cent of Australians travelling to Bali do so without insurance — or around 330,000 a year. 
Cairns’ Joshua Paterson is among those facing a bill for thousands of dollars, after being stuck in Bali since last Friday. Clearing the backlog ... Indonesian authorities at Bali's international airport were fighting to clear a backlog after almost 900 flights were cancelled or delayed in recent days. Picture: AFP/SONNYTUMBELAKA Source: AFP 
He travelled to the Indonesian island with a group of friends, and never dreamt he would be there for almost a week longer than planned. 
“It’s been a bloody mess,” said Mr Paterson. 
“We keep being told (by airline Jetstar) that we’re on a priority list but they are not yet operating services to Cairns.” 
Melbourne’s Primmer family opted to fly via Singapore and Darwin in order to get home by Thursday. 
Sue Primmer said the alternative was to wait for a direct flight next Wednesday 
“We had to pay an extra five nights for the motel. My insurance will only pay for my motel, it won’t pay for food,” she said. 
Most airlines flying out of Bali are not providing accommodation for affected passengers because the situation is beyond their control. 
However Virgin Australia is believed to be putting anyone up who has no other option but to sleep at the airport. Thousands stranded ... Mount Raung has caused chaos for holidaymakers as airports closed and international airlines canceled flights to tourist hotspot Bali. Picture: AP/Trisnadi Source: AP 
Insurance Council of Australia spokesman Campbell Fuller said airlines, insurers and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade were working together to assist people in Bali. 
“Thousands are being helped by their insurers with things like the provision of accommodation and reimbursement for unexpected costs,” said Mr Fuller. 
A DFAT spokeswoman said there was a provision in “exceptional circumstances” for small emergency loans for Australian travellers through the Consulate in Bali. 
But to date there had not been a significant increase in demand for such assistance. 
“DFAT strongly recommends that all Australians travelling overseas take out comprehensive travel insurance,” she said. 
Craig Morrison from Southern Cross Travel Insurance said they had seen a 47 per cent increase in calls from Australians as a result of the Bali ash cloud. 
“Our advice to people who have been impacted by the volcano is to keep all documentation of cancellation from your airline including emails, along with receipts of additional expenses, including accommodation and meals, to submit a claim to your travel insurer,” Mr Morrison said. 
University of Technology Sydney senior business lecturer Dr David Beirman said travellers were typically attracted by Bali’s cheap packages. 
“They do look for ways to save money, and unfortunately, some opt not to get travel insurance,” said Dr Beirman. 
“But as we often hear, if you can’t afford travel insurance, you can’t afford to travel.”
